comments.commentBody:
"DAMON and Pythias are the archetypal BFFs." Don't tell Affleck.

Thanks for the great write-up and musical selections. (I wasn't expecting the Irish Rovers after Miles Davis, though.)

Excellent Tuesday. I like the theme choices and how Miles Davis tied it together. I didn't find anything "mundane" about it--very good fill. It was kinda zippy, but it's still just Tuesday.

I don't get it? Why is Google copying apple? First with their phone and now with their tablet...With all of the brilliant engineers working there can't they come up with  their own ideas for products?

comments.userLocation: The blue house round the corner there.
comments.commentBody:
As I'm not enthralled with the iPad, here are a few things I hope to see on the Google / Android device:

-two USB ports - no adaptors or cables needed.
-the ability to run Windows, Mac or Linux applications (either of those OS' - I suspect that Android is "Linux" at heart - just let me use it as a Linux system)
-128 GB of storage or more.

I need to be able to run "stand alone" - so dependence on "The Cloud" is a no starter.

Need to be able to do:
Word processing, spreadsheets and presentations.
Light image editing ("The GIMP" is enough, Elements would be nice).
Conversion of docs to pdf.
Internet browser.
E-mail
Navigate (GPS/Map application - standalone - no internet access)

Meh....

Does anybody feel Google is fast becoming another Microsoft with all these chase-after-the-latest-fad thingy going on? I mean, what does this or myriad other devices really do beside putting Google's footprint on every corner of the market? Corporate talkers can justify anything with their obscure, no clear path to realty strategy talk, something haunting Microsoft for years. There is just too much me-too going on with Google nowadays: we must have an on-line video site, bam, our service got beaten by Youtube (though we bought it eventually); Wikipedia is hot, let's build one ourselves (why can remember its name?); Oh, let's make an OS based purely on a browser (hack back to the worst day of thin client, something a generation of CS professionals fought to free the world from.); We still have an social networking site (nobody knows its name, everybody uses facebook.), we even bought the ancient usenet archive (how many people are using it now?), checkout, anybody, what's that? Voice, Talk, Wave (cool, just nobody uses it.)....

Yes, Jon, SAS really is the leader in this area. It is pretty much the dominant software for both data management and complex statistical analysis.  I personally prefer other software, but it is not good or bad that SAS is "the leader". It's just a tool.  And I wouldn't expect much in-depth info about the technology.  Otherwise, you would start getting into discussions about algorithms and math.

i'm afraid this isn't good news for adobe, since apple's iPhoneOS is to the mobile web what california is to the car industry.
if car manufacturers have to do it for california they might as well do it for the rest and in the case of flash why bother doing it twice?

only if google were to forgo html5 altogether on android and chrome adobe would have a fighting chance.

having that said the choose between apple and google is more and more like asking a vegetarian what sauce he wants with his steak.

@larry ( comment # 7 ) : Yes, in theory those are all true. But with Chrome browser and with flash as the major media provder, the balance of power shifts to Adobe. After a while most apps will be developed through Adobe CS5 since it is convenient for developers. Adobe is not just the manufacturer of flash, they are much more than that with very big ambitions. They want to have developers developing with their meta layer, so they control the app development platform for many run time platforms without having to do anything regarding the run time platform, its design or distribution and popularity of it. Assume CS5 is the de facto app development platform for Android devices, Google is subservient to Adobe and they need to make sure future Android is compatible with CS5 so as not to piss off the consumers.

Again, this may all be fine with Google since all they seem to care is have their little space to put their ads.

I think the vast majority of men and women appreciate some level of grooming in the opposite sex. Should men just stop wearing deodorant?

Hairy armpits on a woman is not something I particularly like but I could live with it. But hairy legs on a woman? I cannot say why but it makes me gag. Hairy bush on the other hand is far better than completely shaved - it's nice to know you're a woman, not a child. The point is that not all patches of hair are equal.

There's something disturbing about women having no body hair -- especially the whole Brazil wax thing. Armpit hair not that big a deal, kind of erotic, leg hair, not so sure. However, should look R-rated below the waist, not Barbie.
well, let's see. you can be fat, hairy, smell bad,  and get a big hooray. how sweet. what happens if you pick up some lice in your hair, just go natural with that too (hooray).

Women and Hair - dangerous combination.

On or off, we want more.

What do women want?, to paraphrase Mr. Freud.

Great comments above. But can we talk about men's hair?
While there is a double-standard, I think men's grooming standards are rising as well. Chest/back waxing are common, and dare-I-say even male brazilians exist!
I certainly like when the men I date groom their hairy parts too.
And please don't get those hairy legs anywhere near me in the summer time...they're like woolen pants!

I'm female. A male partner once demanded that I shave much more than I normally do. My response? "You first, honey." Unsurprisingly we split up shortly thereafter. The ones worth keeping are the ones who don't ask you to do something they wouldn't do themselves, up to and including shaving.
I've been attracted to at least one woman who didn't shave her legs.

I'm a 35 year old woman and I actually enjoy shaving.  I started in about 6th grade and I do it every day (underarms and legs). Since I do touchups every day, it only takes about 2-3 minutes per day.  When I go backpacking or camping, the stubble really bothers me.  I feel relieved when I can shower and shave again.  I love the feeling of smooth skin.

It's quite funny - we are so easily persuaded to do, and buy, virtually anything.
Equally funny is how more and more guys are convinced to spend money and time on things that formerly only women were insecure enough to buy into.

Nature isn't wrong. Body hair differentiates and accents. It draws the eye. It adds color. It adds interest.

Ask any man who looked at women in the 80s. Many of us long for the day women will throw away their razors and become natural, sexy women again.

Let's not forget Patti Smith's album cover in the 70's, which I remember mainstream disc jockeys making fun of at the time.

I remember reading some memoir of Shelly Winters where she described being in Europe with Marilyn Monroe in the 50's, and the two of them being the only women in the room with shaved armpits. I seem to remember her commenting that they felt ashamed and childlike, being hairless, compared to the women European women who seemed more sophisticated than them, fully accepting of the natural state of their bodies.

I also seem to remember that it was either Gillette or Schick that saw the huge market potential in selling razors to women as a routine grooming tool right around WWII. Prior to that , American women didn't routinely shave either. This is all fairly recent.

I would have never guessed Julia Roberts would be one to go au natural, but good for her.

Last, I read about a study done at Northwestern university that showed that women who applied deoderant right after shaving had measurably higher rates of breast cancer.

So there are aspects of this issue that aren't purely about aesthetics.

Yes! I love this article.  In college, I just stopped shaving all together, it was great.  I loved the stares, which mostly came from women.  With my office job, I do feel compelled to shave armpits or legs when the clothing or season calls for it.  Now I am really into contrast, like going for a Brazilian with nothing else shaved etc.  I say to girls: go for it.  I have never been rejected by a guy for it.  In fact guys are usually ambivalent or surprisingly turned on by it.

I stopped shaving anything years ago. My husband wasn't too thrilled even though he has a fur coat himself. Seeing that he isn't about to shave his back, he can put up with a little hair on my legs. As for body odor, if you wash everyday, you won't stink, hair has nothing to do with it.

What we don't seem to understand is that un-shaven parts of the body appear un-appealing "in the media"...which is what this dialogue is mostly about. In real life (i.e., not on a cathode ray tube, or lcd screen, or hard-copy photograph, or movie screen, etc.); in REAL LIFE, any hair is just a part of that person's persona...for better or for worse. "Wear it right" and you can be attractive; shave, and run the risk of showing something that is distracting... even un-appealing...such as those those nicks and blemishes on those very private parts...
It's official.  The NYT has run out of news.

White type on black background is very hard on the eyes. Years ago I read some study that concluded the easiest color combo to read for long periods was light brown text on a dark brown background. That would also meet your low-light requirements.

If you find an app to do what you want, try these decimal RGB values as a starting point:

text: 153 102 51
background: 35 0 11

That's what I use for Terminal windows on my Mac laptop.
As I read this on my iPad, I switched the settings to white on black. You'd think the Times would do its homework before publishing.
Yup. Stanza does this on the iPhone (and iPad)--you can change the font, its color, background--everything you ask for has been around for at least a year.
